comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/tuncurrymuseum/] has this photo with local knowledge notes in their gallery - www.flickr.com/photos/tuncurrymuseum/galleries/7215762393.... Baths opened in January 1936 - SMH 20/1/1936 p.10 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17208380 SLNSW has a print of this image dated as "9/1937" - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=200322 And three other related photos in the series - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au//item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=200321 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=200317 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=200318 I vote for 1937!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/48420463@N05] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Sorry to solve this too quickly.  An extra challenge - what DAY in September 1937 was it?!

I was beachcombing near Forster today (14/3/13) and called in at the ocean baths to get a 'NOW' photo - the place looked marvellous, with lots of old folk doing aqua-aerobics in the pool, chatting and sunbaking. That's 75+ years of pleasure the baths have given so far ...

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia/8557084546/]

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Excellent - thanks for the "now" photo for comparison! Looks like the sand dunes have made way for high rise.

comment.author: 65411336@N05
comment._content:
The 1937 background is so much nicer! When I first started going there in the mid 60s there used to be only a couple of small hotels like the "Surf Riders Hotel". As soon as Forster got town water that's when the building boom began and the little country beach town was no more. 

I note from the picture the change rooms / shower building doesn't appear to be in place at that time.

comment.author: 97974874@N00
comment._content: A sign appeared at the baths a few years ago now showing how these baths are cleaned. The baths earned a reputation during the 1980s and early 90s for being unclean and became known locally as the Bullring. This was generally an unfair character assassination. While occasionally trapping stormy sea foam and flotsam giving the appearance of being unclean, the water inside was in reality not much different to the sea outside the baths walls. Council had a strict testing program that ensured the water quality and cleaning was carried out at regular intervals during this time. Nevertheless this did not satisfy some people who stridently challenged Great Lakes Council maintenance protocols at every opportunity, perhaps as a means to promote their own agenda to force council to build a 50m pool in Forster. A small number of students were denied permission from their parents to swim in the pool at school PE lessons and swimming carnivals during the 1980's adding to the public pressure on council to build a chlorinated pool. Of course the popularised name 'The Bullring' did not help council in their determination to defend their cleaning regime which including oyster shell removal and replacement of sand on the pool floor. Council eventually committed to building a 25m indoor pool but since then these baths have undergone staged renewal on many fronts and they are now a first class facility enjoyed daily by locals and tourists alike. The baths are barely recognisable today in comparison to the above photo. Here are some images of Forster Ocean Baths taken in 2010.
